content: Both food and human body tissue, meat is symbolic of <span class="fa fa-info-circle">nourishmentspan> and <span class="fa fa-info-circle">decayspan> ![A new exhibition fleshes out man’s relationship with meat](https://cdn.static-economist.com/sites/default/files/20180616_BKP502.jpg) GERMANS’ love of meat is well-known. The country has one of the highest per capita meat-<span class="fa fa-info-circle">consumptionspan> figures in the world, with the average citizen <span class="fa fa-info-circle">chompspan>ing down . In Berlin there’s a museum <span class="fa fa-info-circle">dedicatespan>d solely to the , the <span class="fa fa-info-circle">classicspan> <span class="fa fa-info-circle">sausagespan> dish served everywhere in the on <span class="fa fa-info-circle">crimpspan>ed paper plates. Human-sized, grinning <span class="fa fa-info-circle">sausagespan> <span class="fa fa-info-circle">mascotspan>s can be spotted all over the city outside fast-food stands. Many in Germany consider eating meat, and pork in particular, a key part of national identity. Election posters for Alternative für Deutschland, a far-right party, featured a <span class="fa fa-info-circle">pigletspan> and an Islamophobic slogan, promoting <span class="fa fa-info-circle">prejudicespan> against Muslims’ <span class="fa fa-info-circle">culinaryspan> rules.   The <span class="fa fa-info-circle">complicatespan>d significance of for Germans is contained in the word itself. Meaning both “meat” and “<span class="fa fa-info-circle">fleshspan>”, the term <span class="fa fa-info-circle">designatespan>s human bodily matter as well as what goes on a plate. It is these tangled <span class="fa fa-info-circle">connotationspan>s that a new exhibition at the Altes Museum digs into, utilising the <span class="fa fa-info-circle">breadthspan> of the State Museum’s historical and ethnographical collections to <span class="fa fa-info-circle">dissectspan> the <span class="fa fa-info-circle">obsessionspan> with bodily tissue. It takes a cross-<span class="fa fa-info-circle">Cultspan>ural approach, organised around themes of “Food”, “<span class="fa fa-info-circle">Cultspan>” and “Body”. The 70-odd artefacts on display span Chinese tablets from the 2nd century BC to <span class="fa fa-info-circle">contemporaryspan> American performance art and a “<span class="fa fa-info-circle">Percyspan> Pig” <span class="fa fa-info-circle">cuddlyspan> toy made this year.  It is only recently that Western consumers have become separated from the meat they eat. Photos from the 1970s show “meat <span class="fa fa-info-circle">carrierspan>s” walking down a Berlin street with hacked-open carcasses hanging around their necks like travel pillows. A huge <span class="fa fa-info-circle">butcherspan>’s hook from 1600 hangs <span class="fa fa-info-circle">solemnlyspan> in a glass case as a reminder that this <span class="fa fa-info-circle">grislyspan>, wrought-iron object is how dead <span class="fa fa-info-circle">fleshspan> has been stored for much of human history: it makes today’s supermarkets, with their packaged <span class="fa fa-info-circle">sausagespan>s and frozen <span class="fa fa-info-circle">lambspan> <span class="fa fa-info-circle">chopspan>s, look bloodlessly sanitised by contrast. This change in the visibility of animal <span class="fa fa-info-circle">slaughterspan> informs Christian Jankowski’s <span class="fa fa-info-circle">humorousspan> work “The Hunt” from 1992, in which the performance artist took a bow and <span class="fa fa-info-circle">arrowspan> into a supermarket to “hunt down” his weekly shop. A frozen chicken, toilet paper and <span class="fa fa-info-circle">margarinespan> all get pinged with Mr Jankowski’s <span class="fa fa-info-circle">arrowspan>s, but his hunter-<span class="fa fa-info-circle">gathererspan> approach only takes him as far as the till, where the <span class="fa fa-info-circle">cashierspan> patiently puts through each of his <span class="fa fa-info-circle">piercespan>d purchases. The exhibition ranges beyond food to explore other pleasures of the <span class="fa fa-info-circle">fleshspan>, as in a collection of Roman <span class="fa fa-info-circle">phallusspan> <span class="fa fa-info-circle">pendantspan>s. Two statues both in gold—a <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Venusspan> or Fortuna from the mid-16th century and a “<span class="fa fa-info-circle">musclemanspan>” from the 18th—are <span class="fa fa-info-circle">juxtaposespan>d. The male is <span class="fa fa-info-circle">sinewyspan> and defined; the woman <span class="fa fa-info-circle">buxomspan> and rounded. The <span class="fa fa-info-circle">dichotomyspan> is a reminder of the sexual attraction of <span class="fa fa-info-circle">fleshspan> as well as the need for <span class="fa fa-info-circle">nutritionspan>, for filling <span class="fa fa-info-circle">fleshspan> out.  And while the “right” kind of <span class="fa fa-info-circle">nakedspan> <span class="fa fa-info-circle">fleshspan> can be a sexual turn-on, it can also be a reminder of human <span class="fa fa-info-circle">decayspan>. A wooden engraving of Death from the 16th century shows the figure grasping at a young woman, <span class="fa fa-info-circle">nudespan> except for her <span class="fa fa-info-circle">jewelspan>s: his <span class="fa fa-info-circle">skeletalspan> frame seeks out her <span class="fa fa-info-circle">femininespan> youth. It is a symbol that has cross-cultural appeal. A small, pre-Columbian <span class="fa fa-info-circle">clayspan> <span class="fa fa-info-circle">sculpturespan> from <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Peruspan> <span class="fa fa-info-circle">depictspan>s a woman masturbating the figure of Death, his hand reaching for her mouth. Even when it belongs to the very symbol of <span class="fa fa-info-circle">decayspan>, <span class="fa fa-info-circle">fleshspan> is <span class="fa fa-info-circle">portrayspan>ed as craving life, youth and <span class="fa fa-info-circle">fertilityspan>. The exhibition takes the visitor full circle here, from dead animal meat being consumed by humans for <span class="fa fa-info-circle">nourishmentspan> to their own <span class="fa fa-info-circle">fleshspan> being consumed by the <span class="fa fa-info-circle">insatiablespan>, finalising forces of death.  There is an odd little <span class="fa fa-info-circle">idiomspan> in German that reads: “Everything has an end, apart from the <span class="fa fa-info-circle">sausagespan>, which has two”. This exhibition, which makes strong, <span class="fa fa-info-circle">sinewyspan> links between concepts, takes the viewer from one end of that little <span class="fa fa-info-circle">fleshspan>-filled package to the other.

这项调查揭示了我们所有人身上存在的二元现象。

title: A new exhibition fleshes out man’s relationship with meat
